required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Factors Influencing Perioperative Mortality in Type A Acute Aortic Dissections Operated at Dijon University Hospital
clinical_study.official_title: Factors Influencing Perioperative Mortality in Type A Acute Aortic Dissections Operated at Dijon University Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Type A acute aortic dissections are a rare condition whose natural evolution is catastrophic. Global mortality remains high even if it decreased last years. This is probably due to improvement of diagnostic techniques and the evolution of surgical practices. It is however important to have medical data and statistics obtained in past years in order to better understand the factors influencing peroperative mortality and thereby to continue this improvement.

primary_outcome.description: Mortality during peri-operative acute aortic dissection procedure

secondary_outcome.description: Stroke, Kidney failure, Reexploration for bleeding

arm_group.description: Patient operated for type A acute aortic dissection between 01 January 2007 and 31 December 2017 in Dijon Burgundy University Hospital

intervention.description: Acute aortic dissection treatment include Bentall procedure, Tyrone David procedure, Yacoub procedure or ascendant aortic replacement with or without aortic valve replacement, ascendant aortic root remodelling (all are standard of care procedures)

study_pop.textblock: Patients who underwent aortic dissection surgery in Dijon Burgundy University Hospital since the 01 January 2007 and the 31 december 2017.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients who underwent aortic dissection surgery in Dijon Burgundy University Hospital
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients who died before the surgical incision

facility.name: Cardiovascular and thoracic surgery Unit - Dijon University Hopital

patient_data.ipd_description: All patients are informed before surgery that all the medical data included in the medical record could be used in cardiovascular monocentric retrospective study. No data shared.
